message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The characteristics of the lump suggest an external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for this are drained by the internal pudendal vein, which drains into the internal iliac vein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest an anal fissure or thrombosed hemorrhoid. The bluish color and surrounding edema suggest a thrombosed hemorrhoid. The internal pudendal vein drains the rectum and anus and is responsible for the vessels that form hemorrhoids. Options A and D are veins that can contribute to hemorrhoids but are not responsible for the vessels that form them. The inferior mesenteric vein drains the large intestine but is not directly involved with hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lump around the anus suggests an external hemorrhoid, which is supplied by branches of the internal pudendal vein. The other options do not supply blood vessels to the area.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and appearance of the lump suggest a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for this condition are drained by the internal pudendal vein.

We refer to the anatomy of the anus and rectum for help. The symptoms described suggest the patient has a thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for the formation of this lump drain into the internal pudendal vein. Option A (internal hemorrhoids) refers to veins within the anal canal, not external ones. Option C (inferior mesenteric) refers to veins draining the left side of the colon, and option D (middle rectal) refers to veins draining the rectum and anus but not specifically associated with external hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation, including the tender bluish lump on the right side of the anus with surrounding edema, suggests an acute thrombosed external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for hemorrhoids are draining into the internal iliac vein, which receives blood from the internal pudendal vein. Therefore, the answer is internal pudendal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lump on the right side of the anus that is bluish and surrounded by edema suggests an external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for the formation of external hemorrhoids are drained by the internal pudendal vein. Therefore, the correct answer is (B). Internal hemorrhoids are formed by dilation of the superior and inferior hemorrhoidal veins, and they are not visible without an anoscope. Inferior mesenteric vein drains the left part of the transverse colon, descending colon, sigmoid colon, and upper rectum. Middle rectal vein drains the lower rectum and anal canal below the pectinate line. Neither of them is responsible for external hemorrhoids.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the lump suggests an external thrombosed hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for the formation of this hemorrhoid drain into the internal pudendal vein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and characteristics of the lump suggest an external hemorrhoid, and the veins responsible for the formation of this lump drain into the internal pudendal vein. Option (A) is incorrect as internal hemorrhoids are not visible without the aid of an anoscope. Option (C) is incorrect as the inferior mesenteric vein does not drain the anus. Option (D) is incorrect as the middle rectal vein drains into the internal iliac vein, not the internal pudendal vein.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location and characteristics of the lump suggest an external hemorrhoid. The vessels responsible for the formation of external hemorrhoids are supplied by branches of the inferior rectal artery, which is a branch of the internal pudendal vein. Therefore, the correct answer is option (B).
